description: Of uncertain or obscure origin, perhaps dialectal. It seems to have originally referred to a lucky shot at billiards.  Possibly connected to sense 3, referring to whales' use of flukes to move rapidly.

entries.meaning: A lucky or improbable occurrence, with the implication that the occurrence could not be repeated.
examples: The first goal was just a fluke.

verbs.description: fluke (third-person singular simple present flukes, present participle fluking, simple past and past participle fluked)

entries.meaning: To obtain a successful outcome by pure chance.
examples: I fluked a pass in the multiple-choice exam.

entries.meaning: (snooker) To fortuitously pot a ball in an unintended way.
examples: He fluked the other red into the middle pocket, despite the double kiss.

description: From Old English flōc (“flatfish”), of Germanic origin, related to German flach (“flat”), Old Norse floke (“flatfish”), all ultimately from Proto-Germanic *flakaz.

entries.meaning: A trematode; a parasitic flatworm of the Trematoda class, related to the tapeworm.
examples: The man had become infected with flukes after eating a meal of raw fish.

description: Possibly as Etymology 2 or from Middle Low German flügel (“wing”), from Old High German vlügel, from Proto-Germanic *flugilaz (“wing”).

entries.meaning: Either of the two lobes of a whale's or similar creature's tail.
examples: The dolphin had an open wound on the left fluke of its tail where the propeller had injured it.

entries.meaning: (nautical) Any of the triangular blades at the end of an anchor, designed to catch the ground.
examples: The fluke of the anchor was wedged between two outcroppings of rock and could not be dislodged.

entries.meaning: A metal hook on the head of certain staff weapons (such as a bill), made in various forms depending on function, whether used for grappling or to penetrate armour when swung at an opponent.
examples: The polearm had a wide, sharpened fluke attached to the central point.

entries.meaning: In general, a winglike formation on a central piece.
examples: After casting the bronze statue, we filed down the flukes and spurs from the molding process.
